thread.title: Kim Jong-un’s brother 'grabbed from behind by woman who smothered his face with poisoned cloth at Malaysian airport’
thread.title_full: Kim Jong-un’s brother 'grabbed from behind by woman who smothered his face with poisoned cloth at Malaysian airport’

author: Patrick Lion
title: Kim Jong-un’s brother 'grabbed from behind by woman who smothered his face with poisoned cloth at Malaysian airport’
text:
Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
The half-brother of North Korean leader Kim Jong-Un was murdered by a woman who grabbed him from behind and smothered his face with a cloth soaked in poison while waiting to board a flight in Malaysia, police said. 
Kim Jong Nam was waiting for a flight to Macau on Monday when he fell ill at Kuala Lumpur International Airport's low-cost terminal, known as KLIA 2, police said. 
Following initial reports the poison was delivered by needles, it has now been reported in Malaysia that the weapon used was a cloth soaked in liquid. 
Police official Fadzil Ahmat said: "The deceased ... felt like someone grabbed or held his face from behind. 
"He felt dizzy, so he asked for help at the ... counter of KLIA. The police statement (Photo: @elisewho/Twitter) Kuala Lumpur International Aiport (Photo: Getty Images) 
"We don't know if there was a cloth or needles; the receptionist said someone grabbed his face, he felt dizzy." 
However, there is reportedly security camera footage of the incident and authorities believed the two women looked North Korean, according to the Sin Chew Daily , a Malaysian-based Chinese Language newspaper. 
Kim is also said to have complained his eyes were stinging and that the weapon was a cloth, the paper reported. 
Kim was taken to an airport clinic where he still felt unwell, and it was decided to take him to hospital. 
He died in the ambulance on the way to Putrajaya Hospital, the official added. North Korean leader Kim Jong-Un has lost his half-brother after he died after reportedly being poisoned at an airport in Malaysia (Photo: Getty) 
It had earlier been reported two women, believed to be North Korean agents, had poisoned him with needles at the airport and fled in a taxi. 
A statement by Malaysian police has said his travel documents named him as "Kim Chol" with an age of 46. 
Mr Ahmat said that the cause of Kim's death had not been determined yet, but that a post mortem would be carried out on the body. 
"So far there are no suspects, but we have started investigations and are looking at a few possibilities to get leads," Fadzil told Reuters. 
He was confirmed dead by Malaysian police, and was believed to be in his mid-40s. Kim Jong Nam (Photo: AFP) Kim Jong-Nam at Beijing airport in 2007 (Photo: AFP) 
Kim Jong Nam, 45, was poisoned by two women believed to be North Korean operatives at Kuala Lumpur International Airport, according to South Korean media. 
Kim died after being rushed to hospital but the women were still reportedly on the run. 
The older half brother of the North Korean leader, Kim was known to be based mostly outside of his home country and had spoken out publicly against his family's dynastic control of the isolated state. Read More Kim Jong-un claims North Korea has launched missile capable of carrying nuclear warhead 
A source close to the Malaysian Prime Minister's office said Mr Kim was killed, saying his body was now undergoing an autopsy, the BBC reported. 
Police in Malaysia said an unidentified North Korean man had died en route to hospital from Kuala Lumpur airport on Monday. 
Abdul Aziz Ali, police chief for the Sepang district, said the man's identity had not been verified. Kim Jong-Nam at Narita airport near Tokyo in 2001 (Photo: AFP) 
An employee in the emergency ward of Putrajaya hospital said a deceased Korean there was born in 1970 and surnamed Kim. 
Identification and details of the death were reported by South Korea's TV Chosun, a cable television network, citing multiple South Korean government sources. Kim Jong-Nam at Narita airport near Tokyo in 2001 (Photo: Reuters) Kim Jong-Nam at Narita airport near Tokyo in 2001 (Photo: Reuters) Read More North Korea 'will self destruct unless it stops testing long-range ballistic missiles' 
The South Korean government source who spoke to Reuters did not immediately provide further details. 
South Korea's foreign ministry said it could not confirm the reports, and the country's intelligence agency could not immediately be reached for comment. 
In 2001, Kim Jong Nam was caught at an airport in Japan traveling on a fake passport, saying he had wanted visit Tokyo Disneyland. Kim Jong Nam in Macau in 2010 (Photo: AFP) 
Kim Jong Nam and Kim Jong Un are both sons of former leader Kim Jong Il, who died in late 2011, but they had different mothers. 
Kim Jong Nam was believed to be close to his uncle, Jang Song Thaek, who was North Korea's second most powerful man before being executed on Kim Jong Un's orders in 2013. 
Kim Jong Nam was said to be the heir to his father's leadership. Kim Jong-Il in 2001 (Photo: Getty) 
He was known to travel to Hong Kong, Macau and mainland China. 
He said several times over the years that he had "no interest in leading his country." 
"Personally I am against third-generation succession," he told Japan's Asahi TV in 2010, before his younger brother had succeeded their father. 
"I hope my younger brother will do his best for the sake of North Koreans' prosperous lives." 
Malaysia is one of a dwindling number of countries that has close relations with North Korea, which is under tightening global sanctions over its nuclear tests and ballistic missile launches, the latest of which took place on Sunday. 
Malaysians and North Koreans can visit each other's country without visas. Like us on Facebook
